Dave--

Congratulations, I'm glad that you got a promotion at Caltech.  
Although I'm sad that you'll have less time for us! ;-)

Several questions:

1.  I can't find any directories named ext/tpx in the CANTERA source 
distribution (\src).  Only \src\converters, \src\oneD, 
\src\transport and \src\zeroD.

The only file I can find that containg ext or tpx is EOS_TPX.h.

I can find no files with ext in the name.

2.  Does this mean that the current C++ code of CANTERA supports 
calculations of 2-phase equilibrium properties (i.e. liquid/gas and 
solid/gas such as water/air and ice/air)?  

3.  I ask #2 in because Message 167 (from Alessandro Veneroni) you 
say:

"Multiphase equilibrium is not currently implemented. But you can do 
it yourself. . ."

TIA,

--Keith

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Keith,
> 
> The capabiities you want are mostly already in Cantera, just not 
in the  
> Matlab interface. See, for example, the files in directory ext/tpx 
in  
> the source distribution.
> 
> As far as when they will make it into the Matlab version, that is 
a  
> hard question.  I have recently taken on some additional 
administrative  
> responsibilities here at Caltech  
> (http://www.its.caltech.edu/~offoffac), with the result that the 
time I  
> can devote to further development of Cantera is now fairly 
limited. But  
> since Cantera is open source, anyone can add features, although it 
does  
> require digging through some source code to figure out the 
internal  
> workings.  One of the goals I have for the medium term is to 
better  
> document the internal C++ structure, so that others can more 
easily  
> contribute to the development.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> On Nov 20, 2003, at 1:02 PM, kdpatch wrote:
> 
> > Dave--
> >
> > 2 questions:
> >
> > 1.  Will the next release of CANTERA allow MATLAB to access 
liquid
> > properties (i.e. H2O liquid)?
> >
> > 2.  Do you have any timing in mind for when CANTERA will 
calculate 2-
> > phase equilibrium properties (i.e. liquid/gas)?  I hope to some 
day
> > be able to stop using the FORTRAN-based NASA-Lewis Chemical
> > Equilibrium code. . .
> >
> > TIA,
> >
> > --Keith
